abstract: We measure rotational broadening in spectra taken by the Apache Point Observatory Galactic Evolution Experiment (APOGEE) survey to characterize the relationship between stellar multiplicity and rotation. We create a sample of 2786 giants and 24 496 dwarfs with stellar parameters and multiple radial velocities from the APOGEE pipeline, projected rotation speeds vsin i determined from our own pipeline, and distances, masses, and ages measured by Sanders & Das. We use the statistical distribution of the maximum shift in the radial velocities, ΔRVmax, as a proxy for the close binary fraction to explore the interplay between stellar evolution, rotation, and multiplicity. Assuming that the minimum orbital period allowed is the critical period for Roche Lobe overflow and rotational synchronization, we calculate theoretical upper limits on expected vsin i and ΔRVmax values. These expectations agree with the positive correlation between the maximum ΔRVmax and vsin i values observed in our sample as a function of log(g). We find that the fast rotators in our sample have a high occurrence of short-period [log(P/d) ≲ 4] companions. We also find that old, rapidly rotating main-sequence stars have larger completeness-corrected close binary fractions than their younger peers. Furthermore, rapidly rotating stars with large ΔRVmax consistently show differences of 1–10 Gyr between the predicted gyrochronological and measured isochronal ages. These results point towards a link between rapid rotation and close binarity through tidal interactions. We conclude that stellar rotation is strongly correlated with stellar multiplicity in the field, and caution should be taken in the application of gyrochronology relations to cool stars.

title: Records, Responsibility, and Power: An Overview of Cataloging Ethics

Jennifer M. Martin: Salisbury University Libraries, Salisbury University, Salisbury, MD, USA

abstract:
## Abstract
Ethics are principles which provide a framework for making decisions that best reflect a set of values. Cataloging carries power, so ethical decision-making is crucial. Because cataloging requires decision-making in areas that differ from other library work, cataloging ethics are a distinct subset of library ethics. Cataloging ethics draw on the primary values of serving the needs of users and providing access to materials. Cataloging ethics are not new, but they have received increased attention since the 1970s. Major current issues in cataloging ethics include the creation of a code of ethics; ongoing debate on the appropriate role of neutrality in cataloging misleading materials and in subject heading lists and classification schemes; how and to what degree considerations of privacy and self-determination should shape authority work; and whether or not our current cataloging codes are sufficiently user-focused.

**Keywords:** Cataloging ethics, radical cataloging, critical cataloging, cataloging values, neutrality, ethical issues

**Acknowledgements**
The author would like to thank Violet Fox, Nicole Kulp, and Audrey Schadt for their feedback on an early draft of this article. The author would also like to thank the anonymous peer reviewers and Gretchen Hoffman and Karen Snow for their feedback on a later draft.

**Notes on contributor**
Jennifer M. Martin is the Cataloging and Metadata Services Librarian at Salisbury University. Her primary job responsibilities include cataloging materials for the Ernie Bond Curriculum Resource Center and the Nabb Research Center for Delmarva History and Culture; reviewing metadata in SOAR@SU, the university’s institutional repository; managing WorldCat Discovery, the university’s discovery layer and knowledge base; and coordinating collection development training for the SU Libraries.

title: The Relevance of Statistical Knowledge for Teaching to Health Care Professionals: Reflections on a COVID-19 Press Briefing

Randall E. Groth: Seidel School of Education, Salisbury University, Salisbury, MD

abstract:
## Abstract
Statistics is an important component of the knowledge base for health care professionals. In this essay, it is argued that statistical knowledge for teaching (SKT) should be considered an important component of their preparation as well. Health care professionals often must help others understand the statistical basis for recommendations they make. A COVID-19 press briefing is used to illustrate the need for SKT when making high-stakes recommendations related to public health. It is conjectured that efforts to educate the public during the press briefing would have been enhanced if the presenters had deeper knowledge of the general public’s common statistical thinking patterns, the typical statistics curriculum experienced by members of their audience, and contemporary tools for teaching statistics. The importance of such knowledge to support smaller-scale individual interactions is also discussed. A call for SKT-centered partnerships between educational researchers and medical researchers is made; such partnerships could be mutually beneficial to the development of both fields and to society at large.

**Keywords:** Dynamic statistics software, Medical research, Pedagogical content knowledge, Statistical knowledge for teaching, Statistical thinking

## 1 Introduction
It is widely accepted that statistics is an important part of the knowledge base for those in the health professions (e.g., World Federation for Medical Education Citation 2015; Oster and Enders Citation 2018). Statistical knowledge allows health care professionals to understand research literature and conduct their own studies. Although the specific statistical concepts to be addressed and appropriate pedagogical approaches are at times under-specified in standards for medical education (Hayat Citation 2014), few would argue against requiring those entering the health professions to study statistics.

This essay focuses on a different type of knowledge that health care professionals should have: statistical knowledge for teaching (SKT). SKT is not equivalent to statistical knowledge. Concisely stated, SKT is knowledge that allows one to make statistics comprehensible to others (Groth Citation 2013). Health care professionals need to help people make evidence-based decisions about courses of action for preserving and improving their well-being (Nelson et al. Citation 2002), though their ability and confidence to do so are sometimes questionable (Rao Citation 2008). Doctors and nurses frequently make data-based recommendations during private interactions with individuals; government officials charged with preserving public health are sometimes called upon to do so on a large scale in public. This educational responsibility was especially visible during the COVID-19 pandemic. This essay argues that having statistical knowledge alone is not sufficient to teach the public about the evidential basis for recommended health practices. It is also important to have knowledge of effective teaching practices that account for how people generally interpret statistics.

The essay begins with a brief description of the nature of SKT and how it overlaps, with yet differs from, from statistical and mathematical knowledge. Then, the notion of SKT is used to reflect upon a widely viewed press briefing in which two prominent health care professionals in the United States tried to explain the statistical basis for COVID-19 mitigation measures and treatments at a critical point in the pandemic timeline. The major statistical concepts they dealt with during the press briefing are discussed, and conjectures about how their attempt to educate the public may have been enhanced by deeper SKT are made. Broader implications about the need for SKT among health care professionals around the world and strategies for meeting the need are then considered.

## 2 The Nature of SKT
SKT encompasses more than just statistics subject matter knowledge; it also includes pedagogical content knowledge (Groth Citation 2013). Shulman (Citation 1987) characterized pedagogical content knowledge as the “special amalgam of content and pedagogy that is uniquely the province of teachers, their own special form of professional understanding” (p. 8). Having subject matter expertise alone does not make one an effective teacher; good statisticians may or may not have pedagogical skill. Pedagogical content knowledge has been studied extensively within the context of teachers in conventional classroom settings (Depaepe, Verschaffel, and Kelchtermans Citation 2013); the present article extends the consideration of pedagogical content knowledge to health care professionals charged with making evidence-based recommendations to the public.

Hill, Ball, and Schilling (Citation 2008) discussed three essential components of pedagogical content knowledge: knowledge of content and students, knowledge of content and teaching, and curriculum knowledge. These three components have been used widely in research on SKT (Langrall et al. Citation 2017). Knowledge of content and students involves knowing how individuals commonly understand, and misunderstand, statistics content. Such knowledge supports knowledge of content and teaching, which allows for the selection of pedagogical strategies that leverage existing student understandings and address their common misunderstandings. A third component of pedagogical content knowledge, curriculum knowledge, provides understanding of the broad frameworks and learning progressions that generally undergird the teaching of statistics.

Along with being more than just statistical subject matter knowledge, SKT is also more than just mathematical knowledge. Undoubtedly, a great deal of mathematical knowledge is needed to teach statistics. However, considerable amounts of nonmathematical knowledge are needed as well. For example, those who teach statistics must know how to distinguish between deterministic and stochastic questions, construct surveys, design studies, and interpret results in context (Groth Citation 2007). Mathematical knowledge is necessary, but not sufficient, for such tasks. Many statistical tasks are highly context-dependent and not reducible to deterministic algorithms and conclusions. At its core, statistics is the study of variation and uncertainty. This stands in contrast to mathematics, in which deductive reasoning can lead to definitive proofs. Mathematical tools are helpful for statistical tasks, yet we cannot expect them to produce conclusions as certain as those of mathematical proofs in most statistical contexts. Reconciling certainty in mathematics with uncertainty in statistics is a nontrivial task. Knowing how to help the public distinguish between statistical and mathematical conclusions during a time of anxiety such as the COVID-19 pandemic is especially challenging, as people naturally seek unequivocal answers to questions that cannot be answered with complete certainty.

## 3 SKT in the Context of a COVID-19 Press Briefing
In the United States, at the outset of the pandemic, Dr. Deborah Birx and Dr. Anthony Fauci were charged with explaining the basis for government-led COVID-19 mitigation and efforts to develop treatments and vaccines. On March 31, 2020, the two doctors employed statistical tools and arguments during a press briefing to do so. The press briefing came at a critical time, as the United States had recorded just a small percentage of its eventual deaths from the virus (approximately 4000 of what would grow to be over 250,000), and audiences for the daily briefings from the White House were averaging approximately 8 million viewers (Grynbaum Citation 2020). A primary goal of the briefing was to argue in favor of extending existing mitigation measures, which included stay-at-home orders, business closures, and maintaining social distance in public. Video of the press briefing was posted online afterward (e.g., https://www.c-span.org/video/?470841-1/white-house-warns-upcoming-painful-weeks&live=). Quotes in this essay were drawn from the government video transcript (available from https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefings-statements/remarks-president-trump-vice-president-pence-members-coronavirus-task-force-press-briefing-15/). The statistical subject matter of the press briefing included models, disaggregation of data, and experimental study design. Next, a summary of how Drs. Birx and Fauci dealt with each of these statistical ideas during the press briefing is given, followed by conjectures about how deeper SKT related to the three main statistical ideas may have enhanced their efforts to teach the public.

### 3.1 Press Briefing Introductory Presentation Summary
Dr. Birx began her portion of the press briefing by projecting the slide shown in Figure 1. Two curves appeared on the slide: one to illustrate the spread of COVID-19 without mitigation measures, and another to illustrate its spread with mitigation measures fully in place. She explained that the curves were based on modeling done by “five or six international and domestic modelers from Harvard, from Columbia, from Northeastern, from Imperial who helped us tremendously.” In reference to the curve on the far left in Figure 1, Dr. Birx stated, “In their estimates, they had between 1.5 million and 2.2 million people in the United States succumbing to this virus without mitigation.” She explained that the curve on the far right showed projected deaths if mitigation measures such as social distancing and hand-washing were fully implemented, saying, “what an extraordinary thing this could be if every American followed these, and it takes us to that stippled mountain that’s much lower—a hill, actually—down to 100,000 to 200,000 deaths, which is still way too much.”

[**Figure 1**](https://www.npr.org/2020/03/31/823916343/coronavirus-task-force-set-to-detail-the-data-that-led-to-extension-of-guideline): Slide 1 in the press briefing presentation. Source: https://www.npr.org/2020/03/31/823916343/coronavirus-task-force-set-to-detail-the-data-that-led-to-extension-of-guideline. Display full size

Next, Dr. Birx projected the slide shown in Figure 2 and said it was from the work of a modeler at the University of Washington who took hospital need data from around the world into account. She explained that the graph depicted what would be possible with full implementation of the government’s mitigation measures, and that the model was being continuously updated each day by using new data. Dr. Birx further argued for full implementation of the recommended mitigation measures by showing a third slide with a graph (Figure 3). She used the third slide to argue that states with strong mitigation measures in place were more successful containing the disease, stating,

[**Figure 2**](https://www.npr.org/2020/03/31/823916343/coronavirus-task-force-set-to-detail-the-data-that-led-to-extension-of-guideline): Slide 2 in the press briefing presentation. Source: https://www.npr.org/2020/03/31/823916343/coronavirus-task-force-set-to-detail-the-data-that-led-to-extension-of-guideline. Display full size

[**Figure 3**](https://www.npr.org/2020/03/31/823916343/coronavirus-task-force-set-to-detail-the-data-that-led-to-extension-of-guideline): Slide 3 in the press briefing presentation. Source: https://www.npr.org/2020/03/31/823916343/coronavirus-task-force-set-to-detail-the-data-that-led-to-extension-of-guideline. Display full size

“It was just a month ago when they started to have the issues in Washington State, but they brought together their communities and their health providers, and they put in strong mitigation methods and testing. And you can see what the result in Washington State and California is. But without the continuation for the next 30 days, anything could change.”

She then displayed the slide shown in Figure 4 with data from all 50 states and the District of Columbia. The slide illustrated the scope of the problem in New York and New Jersey relative to other areas. Dr. Birx showed these data to encourage community-by-community mitigation to prevent spikes in cases in other states.

[**Figure 4**](https://www.npr.org/2020/03/31/823916343/coronavirus-task-force-set-to-detail-the-data-that-led-to-extension-of-guideline): Slide 4 in the press briefing presentation. Source: https://www.npr.org/2020/03/31/823916343/coronavirus-task-force-set-to-detail-the-data-that-led-to-extension-of-guideline. Display full size

Dr. Birx ended the formal presentation portion of the press briefing by showing and discussing the slide in Figure 5. It was meant to further support her contention that mitigation measures should be fully implemented. Dr. Birx stated,

[**Figure 5**](https://www.npr.org/2020/03/31/823916343/coronavirus-task-force-set-to-detail-the-data-that-led-to-extension-of-guideline): Slide 5 in the press briefing presentation. Source: https://www.npr.org/2020/03/31/823916343/coronavirus-task-force-set-to-detail-the-data-that-led-to-extension-of-guideline. Display full size

“So this is what gives us a lot of hope. This is the case finding in Italy. And you can see that they’re beginning to turn the corner in new cases. They’re entering their fourth week of full mitigation and showing what is possible when we work together as a community, as a country, to change the course of this pandemic together.”

Dr. Birx closed her portion of the presentation by asking the audience to continue existing mitigation measures for an additional 30 days. Dr. Fauci then came to the microphone to support her request. He warned the audience that the effects of mitigation might not be apparent immediately, and to not be discouraged if cases continued to rise in the short term. He finished his formal comments by stating the following about the government’s recommended mitigation measures:

“It’s inconvenient from a societal standpoint, from an economic standpoint to go through this, but this is going to be the answer to our problems. So let’s all pull together and make sure, as we look forward to the next 30 days, we do it with all the intensity and force that we can.”

After the formal presentation portion of the press briefing, Dr. Birx and Dr. Fauci responded to questions from reporters in attendance. Several questions and responses are incorporated in the next three subsections, because they help reveal how statistical ideas and claims included in the formal presentation portion of the press briefing were interpreted by the audience.

### 3.2 SKT and Statistical Models
During the question-and-answer portion of the press briefing, reporters asked about the model projections Dr. Birx had provided (Figure 1). One reporter began this line of questioning by asking, “Just to be clear, what is the projected death toll, should the people be reasonably good at following these mitigation measures?” Dr. Birx responded,

“So, of course, this is a projection, and it’s a projection based on using very much what’s happened in Italy and then looking at all the models. And so, as you saw on that slide, that was our real number—that 100,000 to 200,000. And we think that that is the range. We really believe and hope every day that we can do a lot better than that—because that’s not assuming 100 percent of every American does everything that they’re supposed to be doing. But I think that’s possible.”

Dr. Fauci added, “The modeling that Dr. Birx showed predicts that number that you saw—we don’t accept that number that that’s what’s going to be; we’re going to be doing everything we can to get it even significantly below that.” Later in the press briefing, questions about how model outputs would change in response to different inputs reemerged. Additional reporter questions of this type included:
- What do the models suggest is on the low end if you have full mitigation?
- If 100,000 is the number with full mitigation, how do you push it lower?
- If we had started these practices sooner, could these models be different right now?

The persistence of these types of questions throughout the press briefing suggests that a different strategy for teaching the relationship between model inputs and outputs would have been desirable.

One strategy for teaching the relationship between model inputs and outputs would be to use dynamic, rather than static, graphical representations during the briefing. The emergence of dynamic representations can be considered one of the major developments in statistics pedagogy over the past two decades and an important part of the knowledge base for teaching the subject (Lee and Hollebrands Citation 2011). Rather than limiting graphical representations to the extreme cases of no mitigation and full mitigation (as in Figure 1), a dynamic graph would allow one to see how varying degrees of mitigation might change outcomes. Sliders assigned to parameters could be introduced to allow one to adjust inputs and observe the results. Users of the dynamic representation could then explore answers to questions like those that reporters posed about the impact of timing and extent of mitigation rather than having to rely upon just the two extreme ends of a continuum represented in static graphs (Figure 1). Knowing the educational possibilities of dynamic representations falls within the knowledge of content and teaching aspect of SKT.

As individuals interact with statistical models, it is important for them to know that such models are subject to change based on new data, conditions, and assumptions. Dr. Fauci acknowledged this during the press briefing, stating, “I know my modeling colleagues are going to not be happy with me, but models are as good as the assumptions you put into them, and as we get more data, then you put it in and that might change.” Although the comment rightly acknowledges degrees of uncertainty inherent in statistical models, it also indicates hesitation to question modelers’ authority and conclusions. Dr. Birx’s remarks earlier in the press briefing also contained several appeals to authority, as she named several prestigious institutions involved in the modeling process. It is generally not a sound teaching strategy to rely heavily on appeal to authority, because doing so can encourage passive consumption when active reflection is needed (Amit and Fried Citation 2005). Furthermore, it creates a perception that there are deterministic principles governing a phenomenon involving some uncertainty and variability. An important aspect of knowledge of content and students is to know that human beings have a tendency to favor deterministic explanations when stochastic ones are more appropriate (Rossman Citation 2008). Knowing this can help one anticipate the need to avoid framing stochastic situations deterministically.

An alternative to relying on appeal to authority would be to make the earlier-suggested dynamic model representation available online to the public, keep it up-to-date in terms of the newest available data, and encourage them to check it periodically to see how answers to their questions about mitigation have changed as more data became available. As answers to questions inevitably change in light of new data, the stochastic nature of the situation can become more apparent. This sort of continuous online interaction could foster a more authentic view of the degrees of variability, uncertainty, and predictability in the work of statistical modeling. Another potential benefit of such an approach would be allowing the public to see how their own actions may contribute to changes in the data upon which the model is based, therefore addressing the primary goal of the press briefing. This sort of arrangement could shift an appropriate amount of agency to the public to make projections and influence outcomes. Similar techniques have already been used to help television viewers engage with election data and make predictions. For example, many television networks use dynamic maps during elections to quickly zoom in on data from individual congressional districts and run “what-if” results scenarios based on changes in electoral vote inputs. Viewers are often invited to interact with the representation themselves online (e.g., https://www.cnn.com/election/2020/electoral-college-interactive-maps). Such techniques provide a glimpse at what may be possible for dynamic statistical model representations on television and online.

Although it is somewhat intuitive to expect that various inputs will produce different outputs as one interacts with a dynamic representation, understanding reasons why the same input may produce different outputs in a statistical model is more complicated. For example, Figure 2 shows a wide band to characterize uncertainty inherent in a model. Most inputs along the horizontal axis correspond to not just a single output, but a range of probable ones. Interactions during the press briefing do little to reveal how the audience interpreted the band of uncertainty in Figure 2, but it seems reasonable to conjecture that few considered statistical variability as an underlying factor. Individuals tend to cite contextual, rather than statistical, sources when prompted to explain sources of uncertainty in predictions (Henriques and Oliveira Citation 2016). Qualitative explanations for contextual sources of uncertainty are likely to emerge before reasoning that leads to quantification of statistical variability (Manor, Ben-Zvi, and Aridor Citation 2014). Thorough understanding of statistical variability and its quantification can be difficult to attain even for undergraduates who have taken statistics and/or are preparing to teach it (Lovett and Lee Citation 2018).

It is extremely challenging to address gaps in understanding of statistical variability during a brief interaction. Perhaps the most viable way to help the public develop better understanding of statistical variation is to invest more time on repeated sampling and informal inference activities in schools (Pratt and Ainley Citation 2008). Of course, this would require finding additional instructional time in perpetually crowded curricula, but doing so could improve individuals’ abilities to interpret model elements related to uncertainty such as the band shown in Figure 2. Health care professionals who partner with educators in developing such curricula would be in position to briefly remind the public of their experiences in school when helping them understand statistical variability in the context of health recommendations. Difficulties understanding statistical variability that persist even among those who have experienced enhanced curricula could be documented and used to continuously refine the curricula. Such ongoing interactions between health care professionals and curriculum developers could enhance the SKT of both groups.

### 3.3 SKT and Disaggregation and Contextualization of Data
The projected death toll of 100,000 or more in the slides displayed in Figures 1 and 2 led to a discussion about how individual state data might contribute to the total. During the question-and-answer portion of the briefing, the following exchange occurred:

**Reporter:** Can the country handle that in such a short period of time, within a couple of months? Fifty thousand a month (referring to projection of 100,000 deaths shown in Figure 1).

**Dr. Fauci:** You know, it will be difficult. I mean, no one is denying the fact that we are going through a very, very difficult time right now. I mean, we’re seeing what’s happening in New York. That is really, really tough. And if you extrapolate that to the nation, that will be really tough. But that’s what it is, Jim, and we’re going to have to be prepared for that.

**Dr. Birx:** Yeah, I think because the model—that model that was from IHME (Figure 2)—that’s based and heavily ladened by the data that has come in from New York and New Jersey and Connecticut. So, you know, that can skew to a higher peak and more significant mortality. If all of the other states are able—and all the other metro areas are able to hold that case number down, then it’s a very different picture, but you have to predict on the data you have, which is heavily skewed to New York and New Jersey.

Later in the press briefing, when Dr. Birx was asked if the New York and New Jersey infection patterns (Figure 3) were likely to occur in other states, she replied, “That’s the piece that we’re trying to prevent in New Orleans, in Detroit, in Chicago, and in Boston right now, and trying to make sure that each of those cities work more like California than the New York metro area.”

In drawing contrasts among states, Drs. Birx and Fauci implicitly acknowledged the important statistical principal that “data are not just numbers, they are numbers with a context” (Cobb and Moore Citation 1997, p. 801). In this case, they tried to convince the audience that it would be more desirable to create contextual circumstances across the United States that resembled those in California rather than those in New York. At one point, Dr. Birx tried to explain the differences in mitigation and timing across states, saying that officials in Washington state and California “really talked to their communities and decided to mitigate” a week or two in advance of New York and New Jersey. She believed this explained why the New York and New Jersey case graphs had large spikes (Figures 3 and 4) and Washington and California did not.

The connections between data and context Dr. Birx discussed led to mitigation measures in some states, but in other states, some governors quickly cast mitigation measures aside. Various political considerations likely influenced their choices. It is beyond the scope of this essay to review all of these considerations, but it seems likely that statistical reasoning also played a role. Historically, many enacted statistics curricula have suffered from lack of attention to forging connections between data and context (Jones and Tarr Citation 2010; Makar and Ben-Zvi Citation 2011); efforts to facilitate this type of reasoning in schools are relatively new (Pfannkuch Citation 2018). Those with this curricular knowledge, another aspect of SKT, can anticipate a need for a stronger attempt to prompt the audience to build statistical knowledge by “continual shuttling backwards and forwards between thinking in the context sphere and the statistical sphere” (Wild and Pfannkuch Citation 1999, p. 228). Engaging in this type of shuttling allows learners to make conjectures about why observed trends in data are happening and what they mean.

The spaghetti chart slides used during the press briefing (Figures 3 and 4) do provide starting points for reconciling data and context, as they disaggregated data by region. The main difficulty, however, is they do not readily provide information about the contextual dynamics of each region. Hyperlinking each spaghetti strand to a table and map with details about contextual dynamics for the region it represents may help. Each spaghetti strand could potentially be linked to tables containing information such as mitigation measures, timing of mitigation, types of mitigation, amount of testing, number of cases, number of deaths, maps showing where cases have been clustered, and any other information needed to understand the given region. The ability to link multiple types of representations, on a single screen, for seamless exploration, is another notable technology-based advance in statistics pedagogy over the past two decades (Mojica, Azmy, and Lee Citation 2019). Knowing of these linking abilities and their potential uses can be considered another aspect of knowledge of content and teaching within SKT. Putting an interactive representation of this nature online (as has been done with dynamic election maps) could make it readily accessible to viewers after the press briefing. Presenters at the press briefing could demonstrate how the display works, encourage others to explore further after the press conference, and make efforts to spread the representation via social media after the press briefing.

As the public examines statistics such as number of cases and number of deaths in a given region, learning supports to help them discern the affordances and limitations of each statistic would also be desirable. The activities of reading behind the data (Shaughnessy Citation 2007) and exploring limitations of statistics (Whitin Citation 2006) have also historically been neglected in many statistics curricula. Knowing this about the curriculum (an aspect of SKT) allows one to anticipate the need to remediate gaps in public knowledge. Relying on a single statistic, such as the number of cases documented, greatly weakens the conclusions one can draw from the data, yet it was a common tendency during the pandemic (Bronner Citation 2020). Considering complementary information such as number of deaths, hospitalizations, and amount of testing can help one draw more reliable conclusions. Using the press briefing to seed healthy skepticism about the amount of information any statistic on its own can provide and then encouraging online exploration of the earlier-recommended dynamic and linked representations may help the public appreciate important nuances of the situation.

### 3.4 SKT and Experimental Study Design
Near the conclusion of the press briefing, discussion turned toward vaccine development. A reporter asked, “How long does that normally take? Weeks? Months?” Dr. Fauci replied “at least months,” explaining, “the drugs that you want to show in a good randomized clinical trial, at very best, they’re going to take months.” The concept of clinical trials emerged again when conversation turned toward development of treatments for those who were already infected. A reporter asked President Trump, “Going back to hydroxychloroquine, how many clinical trial tests, numerically, would you like to see before you put a stamp of approval on it? Because it’s—there are clinical trials being—taking place around the world right now.” Dr. Fauci responded for the President, prompting the following exchange:

**Reporter:** Is there a number? How many cases would you like to see?

**Dr. Fauci:** Yeah. That is an FDA decision and it really depends on a variety of factors. What I would like to see: a clinical trial that has a comparison to something that is comparable to what it means without the drug. I mean, I keep saying it. I say it all the time and I’ll say it again: It’s a controlled trial that compares it to something meaningful. When that—

**Reporter:** Are there particular trials that you’re watching taking place around the world right now?

**Dr. Fauci:** Well, there are a number of trials going on, not only in the United States, but also in other parts of the world. You know, right now, it’s too early to make any determination, but I just want to get back to what I say all the time: The definitive way that you get an answer is by doing a randomized, controlled, clinical trial.

**Reporter:** Dr. Fauci, on social distancing. Or Mr. President—President Trump: You’re talking about the chloroquine? Is that what you’re talking about? In—specifically, per the last question?

**Reporter:** Yes. Hydroxychloroquine.

**President Trump:** Yeah. No, there are trials going on. But there are also trials going on—we’re trying them on people that are now sick. That’s a very important—that’s a very important trial, to me.

After this exchange, the conversation turned to other matters.

During the exchange above involving Dr. Fauci, news reporters, and President Trump, it was not clear that a shared understanding of the notion of “randomized clinical trial” existed. Reporters alluded to trials taking place around the world with those who were sick. At the time, these were generally observational rather than experimental studies, as indicated by Dr. Fauci’s remarks. The initial reporter question to start the conversation pertained to the number of trials conducted rather than the manner in which they were done. Dr. Fauci then attempted to steer the conversation back to randomized clinical trials. After Dr. Fauci made this statement, though, President Trump seemed to return to something close to the reporter’s original notion of trials, referring to those who were infected and receiving the medicine as a last resort. The entire exchange suggested that the parties involved may have been talking past one another when using the word trial. The knowledge of content and students aspect of SKT can help one anticipate these types of communication difficulties; words such as random and trial that have both well-established colloquial meanings as well as more precise statistical meanings can be particularly troublesome for learners (Kaplan, Fisher, and Rogness Citation 2010). Helping citizens and elected officials distinguish among these shades of meaning is particularly important when personal health and public policy decisions are at stake.

Explicit language supports can help individuals distinguish between everyday and technical meanings of words. Existing research has begun to shed light on the types of language supports that may be most effective. Kaplan, Rogness, and Fisher (Citation 2014) found that a visual analogy contrasting statistical and colloquial meanings of the word random helped improve learners’ understanding. They cautioned, however, that more research was needed on the potential widespread effectiveness of this type of intervention, recommending further research on how and why the changes they observed occurred. Pairing the word random with the phrase clinical trial would likely complicate the intervention further. However, once developed by further research, such interventions could become an important component of the knowledge of content and teaching aspect of SKT. The need for additional research on this aspect of SKT shows that this type of knowledge, just as medical knowledge, needs continuous development through empirical study. Although existing literature suggests aspects of SKT that would be beneficial to health care professionals, SKT is not a static construct ready for simple transmission to users. Both SKT and medicine are aspects of the knowledge base for health care professionals that need continuous empirical development.

## 4 Implications for the Statistical Education of Health Care Professionals
The examples of SKT discussed above are summarized in Table 1. The entries in Table 1 likely represent just a small fraction of the aspects of SKT that are important to health care professionals. From this handful of examples, however, one can begin to recognize that the SKT aspects discussed in this essay can be useful for health care professionals beyond the specific press conference and situation that have been described. Hence, in this section, the potential broader applicability of the SKT elements summarized in Table 1 will be briefly considered.

### 4.1 Knowledge of Content and Students for Health Care Professionals
The knowledge of content and students portion of Table 1 contains examples of common statistical learning issues related to the substance of the press briefing. The first challenge is to develop learners’ abilities to distinguish between deterministic and stochastic phenomena. In this essay, the issue was considered in relation to interpretation of statistical model predictions. The ability to distinguish between deterministic and stochastic phenomena, however, underlies many other medical issues facing the public. For example, people may believe that medical tests provide deterministic results, overlooking possibilities of false positives and false negatives; it is then surprising for them to learn that a test advertised to have 99% accuracy can produce false positives at high rates like 25% under some circumstances (Lyublinskaya Citation 2005). Also, headlines and images in drug advertisements have the potential to lead the public to deterministic conclusions about drug efficacy (Wilkes, Doblin, and Shapiro Citation 1992). Advertisements about one drug being more effective than another can exploit colloquial deterministic meanings of effectiveness rather than explaining the more tentative and qualified statistical conclusions drawn in comparative studies.

It is important for health care professionals to understand the nature, origin, and prevalence of difficulties the public may have interpreting what they read and hear about medicine in everyday life so they can anticipate the need to provide appropriate learning supports. The examples above are by no means exhaustive. They are merely intended to illustrate that the need for SKT related to common patterns of thinking about statistics extends beyond the press briefing considered earlier. The essay examples are also intended to encourage research activity that can more fully characterize the SKT that is needed to educate the public at-large to foster their well-being. Further study of health care professionals in the act of trying to help others understand statistical information could produce a comprehensive inventory of the SKT needed to foster public well-being, just as studies of interactions in statistics classrooms have led to characterizations of the SKT needed by teachers (e.g., Pfannkuch Citation 2006; Burgess Citation 2011).

### 4.2 Knowledge of Content and Teaching for Health Care Professionals
Knowing the statistical thinking tendencies that exist among the public in regard to health issues is important, but not sufficient. It is also important to have teaching strategies that foster sound understanding. As summarized in the second row of Table 1, recent developments in statistics education technology offer options for doing so. In this essay, it was conjectured that dynamic and linked representations would have enhanced the instruction attempted during the press conference. Technology also offers additional options for addressing the learning difficulties mentioned in the previous section. In particular, many platforms afford the ability to conduct simulations that demonstrate frequencies of random outcomes (Garfield and Ben-Zvi Citation 2008). Examining such frequencies can help users develop sounder intuition about issues such as occurrence of false positives (Lyublinskaya Citation 2005) and the likely range of conclusions that might be drawn when an experiment comparing two treatments is replicated many times (Chance, Wong, and Tintle Citation 2016). Although interpreting simulations has its own challenges (Case and Jacobbe Citation 2018), there is growing evidence that simulation-based approaches are more effective than traditional approaches to teaching inference (Chance, Wong, and Tintle Citation 2016). As research on SKT related to health issues becomes more prevalent, it would be wise to interrogate and continuously improve all of the capabilities that statistics education technology currently has to offer to support the development of knowledge of content and teaching.

Many attempts to provide technology-based learning supports for interpreting COVID-19 data and models did, in fact, emerge as the pandemic spread. For example, some websites used dynamic models that allowed for the alteration of inputs and outputs to help users see how the spread of a virus would change in response to different conditions (e.g., https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2020/world/corona-simulator/, https://www.nctm.org/Classroom-Resources/Illuminations/Interactives/Pandemics-How-Are-Viruses-Spread/). Others provided dashboards and continuous updates on data pertaining to the spread of the virus (e.g., https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/, https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/map.html). No such tools, however, were featured during the press briefing considered in this essay. Statistical models and data were prominently featured during the briefing. However, the conduct of the press briefing, which was viewed by millions at a critical time in the spread of the pandemic, did not reflect a corresponding degree of attention to how individuals interpret models and data or contemporary learning supports to help the interpretation process. Given that a main goal of the press briefing was to use statistics to argue that government-created mitigation measures were necessary, a greater degree of attention to choosing appropriate teaching strategies would have been desirable. The need for SKT in this highly visible situation amplifies the need for health care professionals to have similar knowledge to support their private professional interactions with individuals as well; collectively, such smaller-scale interactions also have a large impact on overall public health.

### 4.3 Knowledge of Curriculum for Health Care Professionals
The press briefing reflections also amplify the need for knowledge of statistics curricula among health care professionals. People are not blank slates; rather, they bring past experiences to bear in any situation. Experiences with school statistics curricula influence their interpretation of messages health care professionals attempt to convey. At present, it is important for health care professionals to know that many statistics curricula currently suffer from lack of attention to reconciling data and context, reading behind the data, and understanding limitations of individual statistical measures. The impacts of these deficits on the ability of the public to understand press briefing remarks were discussed earlier. Beyond the press briefing, many media stories omit information or make errors when reporting the contextual details of medical research studies (Chang Citation 2015) or intentionally sensationalize them (Shuchman and Wilkes Citation 1997). The public often struggles to interpret and scrutinize media stories in a sound manner (Adams et al. Citation 2017). Many current statistics curricula exacerbate the problem by not including opportunities for students to carefully interpret data in context. This makes it less likely that readers of media stories will probe the underlying contextual details of the research on which the stories are based. Knowing of such curriculum-induced challenges to helping individuals intelligently examine statistical claims is important for health care professionals charged with advising the public.

Of course, there are even more pressing matters than knowledge of curriculum deficits; it is important to work toward sounder statistics curriculum strategies. K-12 curriculum improvements in statistics and probability have been uneven over the past several decades. Once reserved mainly for post-secondary study, probability and statistics gained momentum as strands running through the entire K-12 curriculum near the end of the twentieth century with the release of Curriculum and Evaluation Standards for School Mathematics (National Council of Teachers of Mathematics Citation 1989) and Principles and Standards for School Mathematics (National Council of Teachers of Mathematics Citation 2000). More recently, however, Curriculum Focal Points (National Council of Teachers of Mathematics Citation 2006) and the Common Core State Standards (Common Core State Standards Initiative Citation 2010) removed most probability and statistics content from the elementary grades. Some countries that once engaged young children in studying intuitive ideas of probability have removed probability from their early grades curricula (Langrall Citation 2018). The erratic starts and stops in curriculum reform in statistics and probability have made it difficult to achieve meaningful, lasting progress to help all citizens develop sound statistical and probabilistic reasoning. The COVID-19 pandemic vividly illustrates the pressing need for widespread statistically literacy, lending urgency to efforts to improve K-12 statistics and probability curricula.

At present, health care professionals need to know the nature of prevailing statistics curricula so they can anticipate extant gaps in statistical knowledge they are likely to encounter. Ideally, such knowledge would not only help them carry out their traditional professional responsibilities, but also prompt them to become partners in efforts to improve existing statistics curricula. Such partnerships should aim to enhance the public’s statistical thinking abilities on a broad scale. Meaningful curriculum reform is a complex, gradual process, so efforts of this nature must be sustained over a long period of time to effect change. Recognizing the connections between the public’s statistical literacy and their overall health and well-being may help foster the perseverance needed to develop and build long-lasting partnerships for curricular reform and further SKT research.

## 5 Concluding Reflections
If one accepts the argument that SKT is an important aspect of the knowledge base for health care professionals, it is natural to ask how to include it in already overburdened medical school curricula. One possibility would be to purposefully develop SKT in already-required statistics courses. Models for teacher education provide strategies for addressing SKT and conventional statistics subject matter knowledge alongside one another in the same course (e.g., Groth Citation 2012; Green and Blankenship Citation 2013; Biehler, Frischemeier, and Podworny Citation 2018). One advantage of integrating SKT outcomes is that doing so provides opportunities to reflect on common statistical misunderstandings and how to remediate them. Potential (and practicing) health care professionals are not immune to such misunderstandings themselves. For example, Lang (Citation 2007) reported frequent errors in biomedical journals pertaining to interpretation and use of statistical significance, standard error, and standard deviation. Studying common statistical misunderstandings of others as part of required statistics coursework has the potential to make health care professionals more self-aware of the need to address such misunderstandings in their own thinking. Hence, in a carefully designed course, the study of SKT could actually enhance their subject matter knowledge rather than taking time away from its development.

Even with improved coursework, however, it should be acknowledged that work demands make it difficult for health care professionals to stay abreast of all emerging research on the teaching and learning of statistics. In regard to the press briefing considered in this essay, for example, the technology-based pedagogical tools recommended to enhance the briefing did not exist when the two doctors presenting were in medical school. In high-stakes efforts to educate the public, a team approach is needed. The examples in this essay suggest that having statistics education specialists on such teams is essential so that common statistical thinking patterns are taken into account and addressed in the most effective ways possible. If the public is not convinced that mitigation measures are needed on the basis of empirical evidence, the only teaching tool that remains is appeal to authority. Relying on appeal to authority alone is not only unsound pedagogically; in a democratic society it can, and did, cause systematic backlash against the recommended measures. As the so-called “pandemic playbooks” in various countries around the world are scrutinized and revised in the wake of COVID-19, democratic countries would be especially remiss to ignore the role of statistics education in their observed successes and failures during the pandemic.

Just as enhanced SKT can help improve medical education, recognizing it as necessary for medical education can help improve SKT research. To remain viable, both SKT and medicine require continually growing and evolving bodies of knowledge based on empirical data. Partnerships between statistics education researchers and medical researchers would be mutually beneficial. For example, as suggested earlier, statistics education researchers might analyze the clinical practice of doctors by using tools that have been developed to examine teachers’ SKT in conventional classroom settings (e.g., Pfannkuch Citation 2006; Burgess Citation 2011). As another example, technology-based teaching tools could be examined for their effectiveness in health care contexts and then refined in response to peoples’ thinking about them; such investigations could benefit from methods and tools developed for design-based research in statistics (Bakker and van Eerde Citation 2015) that allow researchers to develop and improve the tools in a bootstrapping fashion. This essay only scratches the surface in providing direction for partnerships between statistics education researchers and medical researchers. The conjectures offered herein provide potential starting points for such efforts, but many other focus areas are ripe for identification and empirical study.

In closing, it is useful to revisit Shulman’s (Citation 1987) original characterization of pedagogical content knowledge as the “special amalgam of content and pedagogy that is uniquely the province of teachers, their own special form of professional understanding” (p. 8). In light of the examples offered in this essay, one might question whether such knowledge should really be just “uniquely the province of teachers.” Or, if one holds to the original characterization, it must be acknowledged that health care professionals need to be considered statistics teachers in their own right. In any case, we must find ways to better prepare them to carry out their teaching functions and provide extra support as needed, especially in large-scale, high-stakes scenarios such as COVID-19. Improving society’s capacity to more effectively teach statistical thinking before and during situations where public health hangs in the balance is paramount.

title: Entrepreneurial Processes and Industry Development:The Case of Baltimore’s Canning Entrepreneurs

Richard C. Hoffman: Professor Emeritus, Salisbury University, Salisbury, MD USA

abstract:
ABSTRACT
Entrepreneurship is at the heart of new developments that often lead to the creation of new industries. This study examines the origins of the canning industry via the experiences of three of its earliest entrepreneurs: Edward Wright, William Numsen, and Thomas Kensett II. The narrative examines key aspects of the industry’s context including the growth in demand for preserved foods, the resources of the Chesapeake region, and the development of food preservation technology. Using the five characteristics of entrepreneurial processes, the importance of entrepreneurs in the development of the economic growth of Baltimore’s early canning industry is examined. Each founder exhibited entrepreneurial characteristics in different ways. One failed in his efforts; the other two succeeded in developing businesses that endured into the next century. The study reveals that using entrepreneurial processes does not guarantee success, and that there are various paths to success. An entrepreneurial multiplier effect was also evident in the growth of firms producing supplies and equipment for canners. Using an entrepreneurial lens offers a closer insight into the development of firms and their industries. Some remaining unanswered questions as well as avenues for future studies are discussed.

KEYWORDS: Canning industry, entrepreneurial processes, industry growth, Chesapeake region, Baltimore city, food preservation

Acknowledgments
I would like to thank Dr. Céline Carayon for encouraging me to pursue this project and for her helpful comments on early drafts. Dr. Hillary Hoffman and two anonymous reviewers of this journal provided helpful suggestions in revisions of the manuscript.

Disclosure of potential conflicts of interest
No potential conflict of interest was reported by the author(s).

title: The effect of regulation‐driven trade barriers and governance quality on export entrepreneurship

Jonathan Munemo: Department of Economics Salisbury University  Salisbury MD USA

abstract: This paper examines the impact of regulation‐driven trade barriers on export entrepreneurship in a panel of 60 countries between 2006 and 2014. The paper finds robust evidence that unfavorable trade regulations significantly reduce export entry rate and export entry density (two critical measures of export entrepreneurship) by increasing the time and cost associated with documentary and customs compliance procedures. These findings support the hypothesis that less conducive business regulations are an important domestic supply constraint which impedes export entrepreneurship by increasing trade costs. In addition, the paper finds that the magnitude of the negative relationship between export entrepreneurship and regulation‐driven trade barriers is significantly more pronounced in countries with poor governance quality. Two measures of governance quality (i.e., political stability and rule of law) are shown to be relatively more significant in aiding favorable trade regulations that promote export entrepreneurship. Furthermore, a reduction in regulation‐driven trade barriers has a positive impact on net entry rate and survival rates of first‐, second‐ and third‐year exporters, and high‐quality governance institutions significantly increase the magnitude of this positive relationship.
themes: Impact of trade regulations on entrepreneurship
Domestic supply constraints in export markets
Effects of regulatory environments on new exporters

title: Integration of Creative Thinking and Critical Thinking to Improve Geosciences Education

X. Mara Chen: Department of Geography & Geosciences, Salisbury University, Salisbury, Maryland, USA

title: Clear and present danger standard 100th anniversary: Examining Donald J. Trump’s “presidential” rhetoric as a clear and present danger

Edward C. Brewer: Communication Department, Appalachian State University, Boone, United States
Chrys Egan: Communication Department, Salisbury University, Salisbury, United States

abstract: ABSTRACTFor the past 100 years, the Supreme Court ruling in the case of Schenck v. United States, 249 U.S. 47, from 1919 has stood as a landmark case due to the Court’s creation of a “Clear and Present Danger” standard of freedom of speech. Through the vehicle of the Clear and Present Danger measure, the Court reconsidered that the degree of freedom for inflammatory rhetoric could be legally permissible until the point that realistic danger of harm or illegal action might occur. One century after this ruling, this paper examines the unprecedentedly divisive and uncivil public rhetoric of a US President, Donald J. Trump. Through a descriptive analysis summarizing the characteristics of President Trump’s rhetoric, we contend that Trump generates a level of dangerous Presidential communication not publicly expressed by previous Presidents that arguably could be considered to overstep the limits of free expression set forth by the courts.KEYWORDS: Clear and Present Danger, president Trump, presidential Rhetoric, first Amendment, freedom of Speech

title: Employment and output effects of federal regulations on small business

Dustin Chambers: Department of Economics and Finance Salisbury University  Salisbury Maryland
Jang\u2010Ting Guo: Department of Economics University of California  Riverside California

abstract: This paper examines the disparate impact of US federal regulations on small businesses. Using a two‐sector dynamic general equilibrium model, we obtained two implications of higher regulation on small firms that have yet to be empirically tested in the published literature. First, as regulations increase, small firms’ share of employment shrinks. Second, as regulations rise, small firms’ share of total output falls. Using a panel of industry‐specific US regulatory restrictions, we found that a 10% increase in federal regulations was associated with an approximate 0.8% reduction in small firms’ share of industry employment and a nearly 1.5% decline in small firms’ share of industry output.
themes: Impact of federal regulations on small businesses
Disparities in economic impacts of regulation

title: On the Way to the Other: Dread, Wonder, Awe
abstract: ABSTRACTImagine a young child who shrinks from—but can’t take her eyes off—a Stranger who’s been invited into her home. This child’s dread-charged awe before the Stranger brings into focus the tension fundamental to our lives—our being torn between openness to the unprecedented future and the desire to protect ourselves from it. Dialoguing with Loewald, Freud, and Heidegger, I consider the radical anxiety the child experiences when exposed to the dreadful not—the absence of the needed. Dialoguing with Aristotle, I discuss how wonder draws the child into harmonious play with alterities that are intelligible to her. However, from the beginning the child is surrounded by alterities whose transcendence overwhelms her. We recoil from such transcendence because it fills us with dread, are drawn to it because it fills us with awe. Dread-charged awe in the face of the other, especially the human Other, is, I argue, the quintessential human experience. Additional information Notes on contributors Jerome Miller Jerome Miller, Ph.D., is the author of The Way of Suffering and In the Throe of Wonder; he also co-edited and contributed to Sobering Wisdom, an anthology of philosophical essays on Twelve Step spirituality. He is a professor emeritus of philosophy at Salisbury University, where he taught for 37 years.
themes: Human experience of dread and awe

title: Multilingualism, Chronotopes, and Resolutions: Toward an Analysis of the Total Sociolinguistic Fact
abstract: In this article, I argue for a chronotopic-scalar system of images and resolutions in the analysis of language use in general and multilingual practices in particular. Drawing on data from Iranian Azerbaijanis, I argue that availability and accessibility of linguistic/semiotic resources, and their categorizations as languages or language varieties, are constrained by participants’ chronotopization histories. That is, the scaled images participants develop through socialization about different time–space frames and the peoples, relations, discourses, and resources therein guide their language use both from and about particular contexts. I discuss the utility of spatiotemporal understandings of repertoires of resources and normalcies in capturing the variability, dynamicity, and complexity of semiotic practices and also in addressing the controversies among scholars regarding the ‘realness’ of languages and hybridity of multilingual practices. Through decentralizing language(s) and foregrounding context(s) and contextualization, I argue, the chronotope enables us to analyze not only social actors’ hybrid utilization of semiotic resources in meaning-making processes, but also their language ideologies and language-ideological practices, which rely heavily on the perceptions of languages as discrete systems.

title: Sustainability Calculus in Adopting Smart Speakers—Personalized Services and Privacy Risks

Hoon S. Cha: Department of Information and Decision Sciences, Perdue School of Business, Salisbury University, Salisbury, MD 21804, USA
Jong Hyun Wi: College of Business and Economics, Chung-Ang University, Dongjak-gu, Seoul 06974, Korea
Chanhi Park: College of Business and Economics, Chung-Ang University, Dongjak-gu, Seoul 06974, Korea
Taeha Kim: College of Business and Economics, Chung-Ang University, Dongjak-gu, Seoul 06974, Korea

abstract: Despite the benefits of using smart speakers, serious privacy concerns have been raised, particularly due to their constantly listening microphones. Given the mixture of the advantages and risks deciding whether to use them is not an easy matter, casting a doubt about sustainable growth and development of smart speakers. Using a sample of 559 users in South Korea and the U.S., we empirically investigated the dilemma of users seeking to adopt smart speakers. The results revealed users’ perceived usefulness and enjoyment positively influenced the intention to adopt smart speakers. No direct effect of perceived ease of use was found but this effect was completely mediated by perceived usefulness and enjoyment. Perceived enjoyment was found to be twice as strong as perceived usefulness in determining the usage intention, confirming the hedonic aspect of smart speakers. Conversely, perceived privacy risks were shown to be a significant negative factor. This negative impact was significantly stronger in the U.S. than in South Korea. We could infer that the more mature the stage of acceptance of smart speakers, the greater the sensitivity of users to privacy risks. Lastly, in the South Korean sample, we found that the perceived usefulness could reduce the negative impact of perceived risks on the intention. to adopt smart speakers.
themes: Impact of privacy on technology adoption

title: A Culture of Organizational Grit From the Perspective of U.S. Military Officers: A Qualitative Inquiry

Celeste Raver Luning: Department of Leadership, Ethics, and Law, U.S. Naval Academy, Annapolis, MD, USA
Prince A. Attoh: Department of Social Sciences, University of Maryland Eastern Shore, Princess Anne, MD, USA
Tao Gong: Department of Social Sciences, University of Maryland Eastern Shore, Princess Anne, MD, USA
James T. Fox: Department of Education Leadership, Seidel School of Education, Salisbury University, MD, USA

abstract: With the backdrop of the utility of grit at the individual level, speculation has begun to circulate that grit may exist as an organizational level phenomenon. To explore this potential construct, this study used an exploratory, qualitative research design. This study explored grit at the organizational level by interviewing leaders’ perceptions of what may be a culture of organizational grit. Participants included 14 U.S. military officers. Seven themes emerged relative to the research question: “What do U.S. military officers perceive as a culture of organizational grit?” Themes included professional pride, team unity, resilience-determination, mission accomplishment, core values, growth mindset, and deliberate practice. This study indicated that a culture of organizational grit is likely a combination of converging organizational elements. Overall, findings indicate that there may be a culture of organizational grit in the military and at the least, more research examining the concept is warranted.

title: Buchwald–Hartwig Amination, High-Throughput Experimentation, and Process Chemistry: An Introduction via Undergraduate Laboratory Experimentation

Bailee Wathen: Department of Chemistry, Henson School of Science and Technology, Salisbury University, 1101 Camden Avenue, Salisbury, Maryland 21801, United States
Emily Lanehart: Department of Chemistry, Henson School of Science and Technology, Salisbury University, 1101 Camden Avenue, Salisbury, Maryland 21801, United States
Lena A. Woodis: Department of Chemistry, Henson School of Science and Technology, Salisbury University, 1101 Camden Avenue, Salisbury, Maryland 21801, United States
Anthony J. Rojas: Department of Chemistry, Henson School of Science and Technology, Salisbury University, 1101 Camden Avenue, Salisbury, Maryland 21801, United States

abstract:
Cite This: J. Chem. Educ. 2021, 98, 3, 996-1000

Laboratory Experiment

Buchwald–Hartwig Amination, High-Throughput Experimentation, and Process Chemistry: An Introduction via Undergraduate Laboratory Experimentation

This three-part laboratory experiment investigates key aspects of the Buchwald–Hartwig amination cross-coupling reaction through guided-inquiry learning strategies. The first part of this experiment utilizes high-throughput experimentation techniques to reinforce, explore, and extend fundamental concepts that are represented in the classroom, including the use of air-free Schlenk techniques and heteronuclear NMR analysis. The second component challenges students to evaluate their results to design, set up, and perform a preparative-scale Buchwald–Hartwig amination. Finally, students purify and isolate their products using column chromatography allowing them to fully characterize their target molecules through a variety of analytical techniques. This experiment represents one of the final experiments performed in the fourth-year undergraduate chemistry curriculum and serves as a capstone learning experience for students.
themes: Synthesis and characterization of chemical compounds

title: When do Mangroves Create an Economic “Safe Haven” from Tropical Storms?
abstract: Evidence suggests that climate change will increase the frequency of intense storms. Mangroves may protect economic activity in coastal areas. We develop a model that illustrates protections from mangroves and coastal elevation and estimate the impacts of cyclones on coastal economic activity. We find that higher elevation or expansive mangroves alone shelter economic activity from “indirect” cyclone exposure whereas economic activity is only protected from “direct” cyclone exposure in high elevation communities with expansive mangroves. Our global mapping reveals that the majority of these “safe havens” are in upper middle-income countries but are used by populations in lower middle-income countries.
themes: Role of mangroves in coastal defense

title: Emotional intelligence and servant leadership: A meta‐analytic review

Chao Miao: Department of Management and Marketing Franklin P. Perdue School of Business Salisbury University  Salisbury MD USA
Ronald H. Humphrey: Department of Entrepreneurship and Strategy Lancaster University Management School Lancaster University  Lancaster UK
Shanshan Qian: Department of Management College of Business and Economics Towson University  Towson MD USA

abstract: Servant leadership is an effective leadership style that focuses on ethics and morality. Emotional intelligence (EI) is also associated with effective leadership and ethical behavior; thus, there has been a surge in studies that assessed the link between EI and servant leadership. Nevertheless, the empirical landscape of this relationship is mixed and fragmented. We undertook a meta‐analysis to clarify this literature and found that (a) EI has a significant positive relationship with servant leadership (ρ̅̂ = .57); (b) the relationship between EI and servant leadership is stronger in studies having a lower percentage of well‐educated subjects, in low power distance cultures, and in high institutional collectivism cultures; and (c) We were unable to find sufficient evidence to support moderating effects of the relationship between EI and servant leadership for gender (male‐dominated and female‐dominated studies), age (between young and old subjects), for self‐report versus follower‐report of servant leadership, and across different scales of servant leadership.

title: Identification of Genes Required for Enzalutamide Resistance in Castration-Resistant Prostate Cancer Cells In Vitro

Sarah E. Kohrt: 1Department of Pharmacology, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, Ohio.
2Case Comprehensive Cancer Center, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, Ohio.
Wisam N. Awadallah: 2Case Comprehensive Cancer Center, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, Ohio.
3Department of Urology, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, Ohio.

3Department of Urology, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, Ohio.

abstract: Castration-resistant prostate cancer can be treated with the antiandrogen enzalutamide, but responses and duration of response are variable. To identify genes that support enzalutamide resistance, we performed a short hairpin RNA (shRNA) screen in the bone-homing, castration-resistant prostate cancer cell line, C4-2B. We identified 11 genes (TFAP2C, CAD, SPDEF, EIF6, GABRG2, CDC37, PSMD12, COL5A2, AR, MAP3K11, and ACAT1) whose loss resulted in decreased cell survival in response to enzalutamide. To validate our screen, we performed transient knockdowns in C4-2B and 22Rv1 cells and evaluated cell survival in response to enzalutamide. Through these studies, we validated three genes (ACAT1, MAP3K11, and PSMD12) as supporters of enzalutamide resistance in vitro. Although ACAT1 expression is lower in metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer samples versus primary prostate cancer samples, knockdown of ACAT1 was sufficient to reduce cell survival in C4-2B and 22Rv1 cells. MAP3K11 expression increases with Gleason grade, and the highest expression is observed in metastatic castration-resistant disease. Knockdown of MAP3K11 reduced cell survival, and pharmacologic inhibition of MAP3K11 with CEP-1347 in combination with enzalutamide resulted in a dramatic increase in cell death. This was associated with decreased phosphorylation of AR-Serine650, which is required for maximal AR activation. Finally, although PSMD12 expression did not change during disease progression, knockdown of PSMD12 resulted in decreased AR and AR splice variant expression, likely contributing to the C4-2B and 22Rv1 decrease in cell survival. Our study has therefore identified at least three new supporters of enzalutamide resistance in castration-resistant prostate cancer cells in vitro.
themes: Role of specific genes in cancer treatment

title: Experiences of Parent-Advocates of Trans and Gender Non-Conforming Youth

Mich\u00e8le M. Schlehofer: Department of Psychology, Salisbury University, Salisbury, USA
Lori Cortez-Regan: Department of Sociology, Humboldt State University, Arcata, USA
Domonique Bush: Department of Psychology, Salisbury University, Salisbury, USA

abstract:
## Abstract
There is a need for more research on the experiences of affirming parents of pre-adolescent transgender and gender non-conforming (TGNC) children. This study explores how parents conceptualized advocacy roles. Eleven parents of TGNC children age 13 and under completed semi-structured phone interviews. Ten parents considered themselves advocates, with digital advocacy being the most common. Advocacy motivations centered around parental concerns. Parents were divided on whether advocacy helped or had no impact on the parent-child relationship. The largest-shared concern was over the right to privacy. These findings have implications for mobilizing parents of TGNC youth as advocates.

**Keywords:** Transgender, youth, gender non-conforming, advocacy, parenting

## Acknowledgements
We would like to thank Christina Cole, Sabrina Dixon, Deija Spencer, and Juliet Vapsva, who assisted with this research, and the parents who were willing to share their stories with us.

## Declaration of interest
The authors have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that would have influenced the work reported in this paper.

**Notes** 1 The term TGNC is used to be consistent with the general body of psychological literature. However, non-binary, gender-expansive, and gender-creative people also fall under this umbrella.

## Additional information
**Funding:** This work was supported by the Society for the Psychological Study of Social Issues Grants-in-Aid program awarded to the first author, and the Salisbury University Office of Graduate Studies and Research. Domonique Bush is now at the University of New Haven.
themes: Experiences of affirming parents of TGNC children
Impact of advocacy on parent-child relationships

title: Predicting Body-Esteem Based on Type of Sexual Victimization Experience
abstract: Almost no research exists examining the relationship between body-esteem and sexual victimization experience in adulthood. The current study contributes to the literature by examining body-esteem based on type of sexual victimization experience (i.e., none, sexual contact, attempted sexual coercion, sexual coercion, attempted rape, rape). Participants included undergraduate women ( n = 750) who completed the Body-Esteem Scale ( Franzoi & Shields, 1984 ) and the Sexual Experiences Survey-Short Form Victimization ( Koss et al., 2007 ), and had either no history of sexual victimization experience or experience within the past year. Women with no sexual victimization experience did not differ from women with sexual contact experience, but both groups reported higher body-esteem than women with coercion, attempted coercion, and rape experience. These three latter groups did not differ from one another, but each reported lower body-esteem than women with attempted rape experience, who reported higher body-esteem than those with no experience. Findings are preliminary but suggest that body-esteem may be negatively associated with some types of sexual victimization experience (attempted and completed coercion, rape), but not others (sexual contact, attempted rape), and escaping rape may increase positive feelings toward one’s body.

title: Tournament incentives and performance: Evidence from the WNBA

Brian Hill: Department of Economics and Finance Salisbury University  Salisbury Maryland USA

abstract: Players entering the Women's National Basketball Association (WNBA) are allocated to teams based on a draft where lower performing teams in the regular season earn the highest odds of selecting the best players, creating an incentive for teams to lose games. Using data from the 2000–2019 seasons, results indicate that WNBA teams are more likely to lose after they have been eliminated from postseason playoffs regardless of the gender of the coach or general manager. Evidence of tanking is concentrated in seasons after the WNBA made a draft lottery change in 2015, which was intended to reduce tanking.
themes: Impact of policy changes on team performance

title: Hearing and Teaching Soundtracks as a Mother and a Daughter
abstract: This chapter analyzes embodied listening from a pedagogical and unusually personal, feminist point-of-view. It explores how two parts of the author’s identity (being a mother, and being a daughter whose mother died) teach her to hear cinema anew along with her students. By extension, it builds upon other sound scholarship (especially the work of Michel Chion), by stressing that every person’s experiences leads them to rehear all cinema with meaningful results. In this chapter, the author first draws from her experiences of motherhood while teaching the sound track of Babies (2010). Second, she reflects on witnessing her mother’s death in relation to teaching the sound track of a death scene from Ten Canoes (2006). Third, the author connects being in the presence of her mother’s silent body with teaching a conversation from An Examined Life (2008), featuring queer theorist Judith Butler and disabled artist-activist Sunara Taylor.
journal: The Oxford Handbook of Cinematic Listening
themes: Impact of personal experiences on perception of cinema
